children.value: The main thing about functions is that you can plug numbers into the function, and the function returns back some value. But, numbers aren’t the only thing that can be plugged-into functions.

children.html: f(x)=3x−1f(x) = 3x-1f(x)=3x−1
g(x)=x2+5.g(x) = x^2 + 5.g(x)=x2+5.
f(g(x))=f(x2+5)=3⋅(x2+5)−1=3x2+14\begin{split} f(g(x)) &= f(x^2+5) \\ &= 3 \cdot (x^2+5) -1 \\ &= 3x^2 + 14 \end{split}f(g(x))​=f(x2+5)=3⋅(x2+5)−1=3x2+14​
g(f(x))=g(3x−1)=(3x−1)2+5=9x2−6x+6\begin{split} g(f(x)) &= g(3x-1) \\ &= (3x-1)^2 + 5 \\ &= 9x^2-6x+6 \end{split}g(f(x))​=g(3x−1)=(3x−1)2+5=9x2−6x+6​

children.value: The operation of pluggin-in one function inside another is called

When we are trying to recognize whether or not a given function is a composition of two or more functions, we are always moving from the “outside” to the “inside”, where the “outside” function is, generally speaking, the one that appears first.
